senses.sense: to make something possible or easier
senses.dict_examp: I will do everything in my power to facilitate the process.
senses.lear_examp: I found that the presentations and talks about CVs and letters of application were really useful, but we should have been divided into smaller groups to facilitate conversation.

senses.sense: the front part of the head, where the eyes, nose and mouth are, or the expression on this part
senses.dict_examp: She's got a long, thin face.
senses.lear_examp: She has got brown eyes, a round face and white skin.

senses.sense: to show with your face that you do not like someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Joe made a face when he saw what was for lunch.
senses.lear_examp: Making a face, I slapped my forehead.

senses.sense: If you accept something at face value because of the way it first looks or seems, you do so without thinking carefully about it.
senses.dict_examp: You can't just accept everything you read in the newspapers at face value.
senses.lear_examp: People are assessed at face value by the type of cars they drive.

senses.sense: to become less respected by others because of  something you did
senses.dict_examp: She had to find a way to accept defeat without losing face.
senses.lear_examp: However, many popular people like Pierce Brosnan managed to keep their lives out of the press and yet be present to meet public demand without losing face.

senses.sense: to manage to stop yourself from smiling or laughing
senses.dict_examp: I can never play jokes on people because I can't keep a straight face.

senses.sense: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
senses.dict_examp: On the face of it, this seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
senses.lear_examp: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage.

senses.sense: while having to deal with a difficult situation or problem
senses.dict_examp: They left home in the face of strong opposition from their families.
senses.lear_examp: No doubt, it was rather difficult to like Enid X. She was hardly likely to arouse sympathy in anybody even in the face of death.

senses.sense: to be the opposite of what is usual or accepted
senses.dict_examp: These recommendations fly in the face of previous advice on safe limits of consumption.
senses.lear_examp: But when we have a look outside our wonderful world, we can easily see that this argument flies in the face of the facts.

senses.sense: something someone does that insults or upsets you
senses.dict_examp: After all that hard work, losing my job was a real slap in the face.
senses.lear_examp: My father noticed that and decided it was high time to take me down a peg or two. He used to work as a volunteer in a hospital for children dying for cancer. One day, he took me there. It was like a slap in the face - suddenly I saw a different world. It was a bleak world, without smiles and happy faces.

senses.sense: to be or turn in a particular direction
senses.dict_examp: Our house faces north/south/east/west.
senses.lear_examp: There is  a desk to the right of the room which faces my bed.

senses.sense: If you face a problem, or a problem faces you, you have to deal with it.
senses.dict_examp: This is one of the many problems faced by working mothers.
senses.lear_examp: Grandparents are experienced people and they can help their children to avoid a lot of problems which they have faced.

senses.sense: to not want to do something or deal with someone, often because it is difficult or unpleasant
senses.dict_examp: I can't face walking up all those steps again.
senses.lear_examp: Everybody at the swimming pool was laughing about me. I couldn't face my family.

senses.sense: to accept that something unpleasant is true and start to deal with the situation
senses.dict_examp: I think Phil has to face the fact that she no longer loves him.
senses.lear_examp: But Mary has a strong personality, she faces the facts.

senses.sense: to accept punishment or criticism for something bad that you have done
senses.dict_examp: If she doesn't have a good reason for being late, she'll just have to face the music.
senses.lear_examp: Teenagers who live with their parents have to face the music about the long bills their parents receive monthly!

senses.sense: something that you say before you say something that is unpleasant but true
senses.dict_examp: Let's face it, none of us are getting any younger.
senses.lear_examp: Let's face it, a life with no physical and mental exercise is something none of us relishes.

senses.sense: to accept that a difficult situation exists
senses.dict_examp: Eventually, he faced up to his money problems.
senses.lear_examp: However, she had to face up to the fact that it was her duty to question the serial killer, to find out what his motives were.

senses.sense: a building or set of buildings where large amounts of goods are made using machines
senses.dict_examp: a car/shoe factory
senses.lear_examp: My friend Martin works at a factory.

senses.sense: a building or other place provided for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: a training/research/medical facility
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, spending the whole afternoon at the lake gives people a chance to try a couple of water sports, which the facility offers.

senses.sense: a part of a system or machine which makes it possible to do something
senses.dict_examp: an overdraft facility
senses.lear_examp: I would suggest free Internet access as an extra facility in our library.

senses.sense: when someone or something does not succeed
senses.dict_examp: Their attempt to climb Mount Everest ended in failure.
senses.lear_examp: David told her that the reason for his failure was her, because she used to press him and she couldn't accept that he wanted to be an actor.

senses.sense: when you do not do something that you are expected to do
senses.dict_examp: Failure to pay within 14 days will result in interest being charged.

senses.sense: when something does not work, or stops working as well as it should
senses.dict_examp: All street lights aren't working due to a power failure.
senses.lear_examp: There has been a power failure but it will be solved in a few minutes.

senses.sense: directly, meeting someone in the same place
senses.dict_examp: We need to talk face to face.
senses.lear_examp: I need to talk to her face to face.

senses.sense: to  become less bright, strong or clear, or to make something become less bright, strong or clear
senses.dict_examp: If you hang your clothes out in the bright sun, they will fade.
senses.lear_examp: Since the cottage is quite isolated, the electric power supply is not always the best. Anyway, the first night, the lights started to fade.

senses.sense: to gradually become less strong or clear and then disappear
senses.dict_examp: With time, memories of that painful summer would fade away.
senses.lear_examp: These memories would never fade away, she knew it.

senses.sense: extremely good
senses.dict_examp: They've got a fabulous house.
senses.lear_examp: Everybody admitted that the entertainment was absolutely fabulous.

senses.sense: the equipment and services provided for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: athletic facilities
senses.lear_examp: The city has more facilities than the countryside.

senses.sense: one of the things that has an effect on a situation, decision, event, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Money was an important factor in their decision to move.
senses.lear_examp: Modern technology is another important factor which affects our life.

senses.sense: something important that helps to make the final decision
senses.dict_examp: Cost was the deciding factor in choosing this builder.
senses.lear_examp: Personally, I think the quality of teachers, school reputation and facilities should be the deciding factors for parents for which schools their children should be educated in.

senses.sense: to not pass a test or exam
senses.dict_examp: A lot of people fail their driving test the first time.
senses.lear_examp: I was told most people fail the exam two or three times.

senses.sense: to not do what is necessary or expected
senses.dict_examp: He failed to turn up for football practice yesterday.
senses.lear_examp: Your advertisement also failed to mention the fact that there were no discounts.

senses.sense: to not be successful
senses.dict_examp: She moved to London in the hope of finding work as a model, but failed.
senses.lear_examp: I tried to make him give up, but all my attempts failed.

senses.sense: to stop working normally, or to become weaker
senses.dict_examp: Two of the plane's engines had failed.
senses.lear_examp: The sound system failed.

senses.sense: used to say that you do not accept something
senses.dict_examp: I fail to see why you cannot work on a Sunday.
senses.lear_examp: I fail to understand why they still refuse to use this media; it could possibly be the main solution to the present problems in the library.

senses.sense: teachers at a college or university, or in a department of a college or university
senses.dict_examp: We are interviewing for new faculty - there are two positions open in the history department.

senses.sense: the group of teaching staff of a college or university or of a department of a college or university
senses.dict_examp: He was part of the computer engineering faculty before becoming dean of the Graduate School.
senses.lear_examp: I think that the strengths of the system are mainly in higher education and in some university faculties.

senses.sense: slight and not easy to notice, smell, hear, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a faint sound/noise/smell
senses.lear_examp: I heard a faint sound.

senses.sense: to feel very weak and as if you might fall down
senses.dict_examp: Seeing all the blood made me feel faint.
senses.lear_examp: Starting to feel faint, Fred quickly roused himself and ran out of the hotel as quickly as he could.

senses.sense: used to emphasize that you do not know something
senses.dict_examp: I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about.
senses.lear_examp: Some twenty years ago, when I left my parents' home to go and live on my own, I was given four mugs. By whom? I haven't the faintest idea.

senses.sense: to suddenly become unconscious for a short time, usually falling down
senses.dict_examp: He faints at the sight of blood.
senses.lear_examp: The young girl was about to faint.

senses.sense: involving two people who are meeting in the same place
senses.dict_examp: a face-to-face meeting

senses.sense: something that you know is true, exists, or has happened
senses.dict_examp: I don't know all the facts about what happened.
senses.lear_examp: I love this book, because it's about history facts and it's very interesting.

senses.sense: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
senses.dict_examp: We met Rebecca for lunch. In fact, we spent the whole afternoon with her.
senses.lear_examp: The club has its own small clubhouse, with many things in it. For example, there was a big pinball-game and some computers.  In fact it was the best clubhouse I've ever seen.

senses.sense: used to refer to a situation which is surprising in relation to something that is true or happens
senses.dict_examp: The company has been forced to reduce its price, despite the fact that the offer has been very popular.
senses.lear_examp: The advantages of the kind of life that people had years ago is that they could eat more fruit and vegetables than us. However, there are advantages for us too, because despite the fact that we eat more fast food, we do more exercise than they did.

senses.sense: real events and experiences, not things that are imagined
senses.dict_examp: It's sometimes hard to separate fact from fiction.

senses.sense: used to give more information, or to correct something that has been said
senses.dict_examp: John plays golf professionally. As a matter of fact, he has just won a big competition.
senses.lear_examp: I think it would be better to choose somewhere outdoors. As a matter of fact, I prefer the open air and the sunlight!

senses.sense: used to tell someone that something is the truth
senses.dict_examp: I wouldn't usually ask for your help, but the fact is I'm desperate.
senses.lear_examp: You may find it unusual for a woman to play football, but the fact is I'm Brazilian and in Brazil it is really common.

senses.sense: of or on the face
senses.dict_examp: facial expressions/hair
senses.lear_examp: I can still recall the doctor's facial expression when he announced the exciting news to me.

senses.sense: cloth
senses.dict_examp: a light/cotton fabric
senses.lear_examp: In our country fabric seldom could be obtained. My mother made herself a winter jacket from old curtains and black stockings from an old woolen pullover.

senses.sense: the basic way in which a society or other social group is organized
senses.dict_examp: The family is part of the fabric of society.
senses.lear_examp: You cannot infringe individual liberties and ban the purchase of cars - it would go against the very fabric of modern society.

senses.sense: not real, but made to look or seem real
senses.dict_examp: fake fur
senses.lear_examp: On the walls there are paintings which are very artistic - one of them is a fake Picasso.

senses.sense: a copy of something that is intended to look real or valuable and deceive people
senses.dict_examp: Experts say that the painting is a fake.
senses.lear_examp: Many of the pictures taken are fakes.

senses.sense: someone who pretends to have particular skills or qualities so that they can deceive people or get their admiration
senses.dict_examp: He said he was a doctor, but we soon realized he was a fake.
senses.lear_examp: So, after all he was a fake!

senses.sense: to copy something in order to deceive people
senses.dict_examp: The documents had been faked.
senses.lear_examp: People liked it so much that another author, using the pseudonym of "Arellaneda", faked Cervante's novel by writing a second part.

senses.sense: to pretend that something has happened when it has not or to pretend to have a feeling that you do not have
senses.dict_examp: They faked illness to avoid having to work.
senses.lear_examp: This situation lasted about two years until Caroline had a great idea: they would fake their death and run away to live a quiet life on a secret island they would have bought under an alias.

senses.sense: great trust or confidence in something or someone
senses.dict_examp: She has no faith in modern medicine.
senses.lear_examp: We must do our best to help these children to have faith in their future.

senses.sense: strong belief in a god or gods
senses.dict_examp: Even in the bad times she never lost her faith.
senses.lear_examp: Your story about Christianity was very interesting and I was shocked at your deep faith in God.

senses.sense: a particular religion
senses.dict_examp: the Muslim/Christian/Jewish faith
senses.lear_examp: Everybody was praying, asking for help according to their faith or religion.

senses.sense: having pale skin or a light color of hair
senses.dict_examp: She's got fair hair and blue eyes.
senses.lear_examp: She is a pretty girl with long fair hair and she has beautiful eyes.

senses.sense: treating everyone in the same way, so that no one has an advantage
senses.dict_examp: That's not fair! You always go first!
senses.lear_examp: Even though she thought her mom wasn't being fair, she decided to go and try to have a nice day with her family.

senses.sense: acceptable, reasonable or right
senses.dict_examp: a fair deal
senses.lear_examp: You may ask yourself: "What do you do in a club?" Well, it's a fair question!!!

senses.sense: used for saying that you can understand and accept someone's opinion or decision
senses.dict_examp: "He says he'll only work on Sunday if he gets paid extra." "Fair enough."
senses.lear_examp: Most of the streets are open to cars and therefore people tend to escape to a little area around the pedestrian streets. Fair enough, but it makes those streets terribly overcrowded.

senses.sense: not very good but not very bad
senses.dict_examp: He’s good in chemistry but only fair in math.
senses.lear_examp: As for grammar, listening and writing skills, they were only fair.

senses.sense: a large amount, distance, size, etc.
senses.dict_examp: There's still a fair amount of work to be done on the house.
senses.lear_examp: Of course it is important to find a job we enjoy and which leaves us a fair amount of free time, but it is equally important to find a job that pays the bills, especially nowadays.

senses.sense: an equal and honest opportunity
senses.dict_examp: All he asks is a fair chance to prove his innocence.
senses.lear_examp: Then again, I think you have to give every job a fair chance.

senses.sense: behavior that is fair, honest, and does not take advantage of people
senses.dict_examp: The public needs to feel a sense of fair play from the government.
senses.lear_examp: He still believes in justice or just the rule of fair play.

senses.sense: an event outside where food and goods are sold, there is entertainment, and sometimes contests
senses.dict_examp: the state/county fair
senses.lear_examp: The annual Leipzig fair is 500 years old.

senses.sense: a show in a large place where people who work  in a particular industry or have a particular interest or hobby meet to sell products, share information, give demonstrations, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a book/antiques/toy fair
senses.lear_examp: The fair was well organized and structured into specific sections from clothing and sportswear to household appliances and electronics.

senses.sense: when you treat everyone in the same way, so that no one has an advantage
senses.dict_examp: He believes in fairness and decency.
senses.lear_examp: I think you have not treated us with fairness and truthfulness and therefore I do think that an apology in the newspaper would be in order.

senses.sense: slight and not easy to notice, smell, hear, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a faint sound/noise/smell
senses.lear_examp: I heard a faint sound.

senses.sense: to feel very weak and as if you might fall down
senses.dict_examp: Seeing all the blood made me feel faint.
senses.lear_examp: Starting to feel faint, Fred quickly roused himself and ran out of the hotel as quickly as he could.

senses.sense: used to emphasize that you do not know something
senses.dict_examp: I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about.
senses.lear_examp: Some twenty years ago, when I left my parents' home to go and live on my own, I was given four mugs. By whom? I haven't the faintest idea.

senses.sense: to suddenly become unconscious for a short time, usually falling down
senses.dict_examp: He faints at the sight of blood.
senses.lear_examp: The young girl was about to faint.

senses.sense: more than average, but less than very
senses.dict_examp: a fairly big family
senses.lear_examp: The weather was fairly warm.

senses.sense: If you do something fairly, you do it in a way which is right and reasonable and treats people equally.
senses.dict_examp: He claimed that he hadn't been treated fairly by his employers.

senses.sense: loyal
senses.dict_examp: a faithful friend
senses.lear_examp: An ideal pet should be a faithful friend to people, especially to its owner.

senses.sense: If your husband, wife or partner is faithful, they do not have a romantic relationship with anyone else.
senses.dict_examp: a faithful husband
senses.lear_examp: Making a commitment to be faithful to another, and to love a person for the rest of your life is no small thing.

senses.sense: not changing any of the original details, facts, style, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Does the film adaptation stay faithful to the novel?
senses.lear_examp: Working with deconstruction in music, he remained faithful to his main motto: Be yourself, express yourself, never repeat or imitate.

senses.sense: to move down toward the ground, sometimes by accident
senses.dict_examp: The path's very steep, so be careful you don't fall.
senses.lear_examp: You'd better wear your cheap clothes as paint may fall on you.

senses.sense: to become lower in size, amount or strength
senses.dict_examp: Demand for new cars has fallen recently.
senses.lear_examp: It fell steadily until 1960, and remained at 3% until 1987.

senses.sense: to start to sleep
senses.dict_examp: I fell asleep on the sofa watching TV.
senses.lear_examp: And I need a bookshelf and a lamp of course, because I always read in bed before I fall asleep.

senses.sense: to start to love someone
senses.dict_examp: I was 20 when I first fell in love.
senses.lear_examp: I fell in love with David.

senses.sense: If an event or joke falls flat, it fails to have the effect that you wanted, such as making people laugh.
senses.dict_examp: All the jokes in his speech fell flat.
senses.lear_examp: The cultural visits fell flat in comparison to their expectations, although the sightseeing tour of Willstown was, as the students said, "fascinating."

senses.sense: used to say that it is becoming dark
senses.dict_examp: When darkness fell, I began to feel worried.
senses.lear_examp: He greeted the worms and the slugs, and as darkness fell he retired to the shelter he had built for the night.

senses.sense: to be defeated and start to be controlled by a different leader
senses.dict_examp: The city fell to the enemy.

senses.sense: to become worse, or start to be in a bad situation or condition
senses.dict_examp: Education standards are continuing to fall.
senses.lear_examp: This impressive, massive 18th-century building which accommodated the Town Hall until recently (5 years ago) has now fallen into disuse.

senses.sense: to hang down
senses.dict_examp: Her long hair fell softly over her shoulders.
senses.lear_examp: She had gorgeous black hair falling down her back, a creamy complexion and a figure models dream of.

senses.sense: If advice or a request falls on deaf ears, people ignore it.
senses.dict_examp: Our pleas for help fell on deaf ears.
senses.lear_examp: His cry for help and for a more meaningful relationship between himself and Mildred invariably fell on deaf ears.

senses.sense: When events or details that you did not understand before fall into place, they become easy to understand.
senses.dict_examp: When Jo told me she had a twin sister, everything fell into place.

senses.sense: to be hurt or deceived by something or someone bad
senses.dict_examp: He fell prey to a gang of criminals pretending to be city officials.
senses.lear_examp: As young people do not have experience in living independently in society and are not fully aware of social problems such as drugs and violence, they may easily fall prey to adults who would like to exploit them.

senses.sense: to not reach a particular level, but only by a small amount
senses.dict_examp: Sales for the first half of this year fell just short of the target.
senses.lear_examp: Furthermore, it cannot be denied that public transport falls short of the target set during the planning process.

senses.sense: to fail to achieve something
senses.dict_examp: His behavior falls short of what we expect.
senses.lear_examp: This routine was really wearing me out, but, I didn't want to fall short of my parents' expectations.

senses.sense: to break into pieces
senses.dict_examp: My poor old boots are falling apart.
senses.lear_examp: It looks like it is going to fall apart any day.

senses.sense: to start having problems that you cannot deal with
senses.dict_examp: The deal fell apart because of a lack of financing.
senses.lear_examp: All her dreams and wishes fell apart.

senses.sense: to use someone or something when other things have failed, or when there are no other choices
senses.dict_examp: We've been saving up the past few years, to have something to fall back on.
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, in an emergency, you can fall back on my neighbors.

senses.sense: to fall onto the ground
senses.dict_examp: Our apple tree fell down in the storm.
senses.lear_examp: When I got up in the morning, I slipped on a piece of soap and fell down.

senses.sense: to suddenly have strong romantic feelings about someone
senses.dict_examp: She fell for a tall, handsome Frenchman when she was on vacation in Paris.
senses.lear_examp: I saw a handsome boy and I fell for him.

senses.sense: to argue with someone and stop being friendly with them
senses.dict_examp: She's fallen out with her sister.
senses.lear_examp: My husband always blames me and we fall out over my incapacity to cook.

senses.sense: If someone or something falls over, they fall to the ground or onto their side.
senses.dict_examp: She tripped and fell over.
senses.lear_examp: I nearly fell over because the corridor was very dark.

senses.sense: If a plan or agreement falls through, it fails to happen.
senses.dict_examp: Our plans to go on vacation together fell through when Jamie got sick.
senses.lear_examp: All our plans fell through and I hope it will never happen to me again.

senses.sense: the season of the year between summer and winter, when leaves fall from the trees
senses.dict_examp: We like to travel in the fall when there are fewer tourists.
senses.lear_examp: You come here in the fall and I think it's best to spend our time in the city because the countryside is very cold.

senses.sense: when the size, amount or strength of something gets lower
senses.dict_examp: the recent fall in the price of gas
senses.lear_examp: There is a fall in job vacancies.

senses.sense: when someone or something falls down to the ground, often without intending to or by accident
senses.dict_examp: He had a nasty fall and hurt his back.
senses.lear_examp: I was terrified and I heard the noise of a fall just by my side.

senses.sense: when a city, government, leader, etc. loses power or control
senses.dict_examp: the fall of the Roman Empire
senses.lear_examp: After the fall of the previous system everything changed.

senses.sense: to teach someone more about something new, or try to understand more about it yourself
senses.dict_examp: We spent a few minutes familiarizing ourselves with the day's schedule.
senses.lear_examp: Also, it is better for you to stay in my house for several days to familiarize yourself with the environment.

senses.sense: someone who owns or looks after a farm
senses.dict_examp: a sheep farmer
senses.lear_examp: The farmer was very friendly and we spent the day with him.

senses.sense: to interest someone a lot
senses.dict_examp: Science has always fascinated me.
senses.lear_examp: What fascinates me about it is that this style of music allows the artist to bring in crazy new ideas such as African or Indian rhythms.

senses.sense: easy to recognize because of being seen, met, heard, etc. before
senses.dict_examp: There were one or two familiar faces.
senses.lear_examp: Someone started to wave and then I saw a familiar face.

senses.sense: to know something or someone well
senses.dict_examp: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with your poetry.
senses.lear_examp: I'm familiar with many kinds of sports activities such as ball games, recreation games, swimming and Japanese budo-karate, judo etc.

senses.sense: someone who admires and supports a person, sport, sports team, etc.
senses.dict_examp: More than 15,000 Liverpool fans attended Saturday's game.
senses.lear_examp: I'm a fan of rock music.

senses.sense: something that is used to move the air around so that it feels cooler, such as a machine or an object that you move with your hand
senses.dict_examp: There was no air conditioning, just a ceiling fan turning slowly.
senses.lear_examp: Since it's quite hot here I brought a fan. I have to use it at night otherwise I can't get to sleep.

senses.sense: a long distance away
senses.dict_examp: faraway places
senses.lear_examp: They transport me to faraway places and to a magic world.

senses.sense: an expression on someone's face that shows that they are not thinking about what is happening around them
senses.dict_examp: He had a faraway look in his eyes.
senses.lear_examp: But her most noticeable features are her large brown eyes and her happy smile. Yet, sometimes you could see a faraway look in her eyes.

senses.sense: when you are known by many people because of your achievements, skills, etc.
senses.dict_examp: She first rose to fame as a singer at the age of 16.
senses.lear_examp: It is certain that these people have fame, fortune and success, and that many of them are very rich.

senses.sense: known and recognized by many people
senses.dict_examp: a famous actor
senses.lear_examp: It is the most famous place in Edinburgh.

senses.sense: a group of people who are related to each other, such as a mother, a father, and their children
senses.dict_examp: A new family has moved in next door.
senses.lear_examp: I will come with my family.

senses.sense: the children of a family
senses.dict_examp: He's a single parent raising a family on his own.
senses.lear_examp: Some people also want to have a family because they want to be a father or a mother.

senses.sense: at, to or from a great distance in space or time
senses.dict_examp: Is the station far away?
senses.lear_examp: It isn't so far from my house so we can go on foot.

senses.sense: until now

senses.lear_examp: What, however, made us very frustrated was that there was no opportunity for us to take an exam at the end of this month.

senses.sense: a flat, metal pan with a long handle that is used for frying food
senses.dict_examp: Chop the mushrooms and put them in the frying pan.

senses.sense: strong, unpleasant, and often dangerous gas or smoke
senses.dict_examp: car exhaust fumes
senses.lear_examp: Cars emit fumes that are very dangerous.

senses.sense: a feeling of happiness because you are receiving or achieving what you want in life
senses.dict_examp: Workaholics find fulfillment in their work.
senses.lear_examp: Having a satisfactory job, the need to seek fulfillment from material things will subside.

senses.sense: the act of doing something necessary or something that you have promised or wanted to do
senses.dict_examp: Being here is the fulfillment of a lifelong ambition.
senses.lear_examp: In general a success is perceived as fulfillment of someone's positive role in the society.

senses.sense: the feeling of being annoyed because things are not happening in the way that you want, or in the way that they should
senses.dict_examp: I could sense his frustration at not being able to help.
senses.lear_examp: So we had to leave hungry and with a certain feeling of frustration and disappointment.

senses.sense: a substance that is burned to provide heat or power
senses.dict_examp: Wood, coal, oil and gas are all different kinds of fuel.
senses.lear_examp: And third, if a rising number of people  use a bike instead of their car, traffic density will decrease which is, again, good for the environment because there will be fewer traffic jams and therefore less fuel consumption and less pollution.

senses.sense: completely
senses.dict_examp: The hotel was fully booked.

senses.sense: If something is fulfilling, it satisfies you and makes you happy.
senses.dict_examp: a fulfilling job
senses.lear_examp: But the choice of a fulfilling job is an important factor because most people spend 8 or 9 hours working every day and doing something that you don't like for long can be a problem.

senses.sense: If a container or a space is full, it contains as many things or people as possible, or as much of something as possible.
senses.dict_examp: We couldn't get in - the theater was full.
senses.lear_examp: I'm selling it, because I haven't enough free time to ride it and my garage is full!

senses.sense: complete and including every part
senses.dict_examp: Please give your full name and address.
senses.lear_examp: I have Diwali holiday which means I will have a full day free.

senses.sense: containing a lot of things or people or a lot of something
senses.dict_examp: This sweater is full of holes.
senses.lear_examp: You could  go to Venice because it is a special place full of art.

senses.sense: the greatest possible
senses.dict_examp: James is very bright, but he doesn't make full use of his abilities.
senses.lear_examp: You could notice he was mad about all the noise we made.  So we left at full speed!!!

senses.sense: completely and with nothing missing
senses.dict_examp: The bill must be paid in full by the end of the month.
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, I wasn't able to read the e-mail in full, but as I understood it, he wanted to apologize for what had happened between us many years ago.

senses.sense: having eaten enough food
senses.dict_examp: No more cake for me, thanks, I'm full.
senses.lear_examp: After having a big lunch, he was full up.

senses.sense: to think that you are very important in a way that annoys other people
senses.dict_examp: I doubt he even thought about what you might need, he’s so full of himself.
senses.lear_examp: There is a thing which I consider very important for the upbringing of my own children - to "teach" them to be coherent and to think of the "others" because if you are full of yourself, you are blind and you can't see what is happening around you.

senses.sense: to be very busy
senses.dict_examp: Shelley has her hands full with three kids under 5.
senses.lear_examp: This very fact made my father work like a slave, as he was the only breadwinner at home, my mother having her hands full with us four.

senses.sense: to show on your face that you are annoyed or worried by moving your eyebrows  together
senses.dict_examp: She frowned when I mentioned his name.
senses.lear_examp: She looked at him and frowned, strange, but he smiled back.

senses.sense: to think that something is wrong and that you should not do it
senses.dict_examp: You can wear jeans, but I think the restaurant  frowns on shorts and sneakers.
senses.lear_examp: Talking being very often frowned upon in the Zen gardens, consequently it is peaceful and so you can fully relax and completely empty your head.

senses.sense: the expression on your face when you frown
senses.dict_examp: He looked at me with a puzzled frown.
senses.lear_examp: If you are truly devoted to your health, logic thus dictates that you will be sitting at the dinner table with an empty plate - and certainly a frown on your face.

senses.sense: an amount of money collected, saved, or provided for a purpose
senses.dict_examp: a pension fund
senses.lear_examp: A fund in her name has been made for handicapped children and the amount in this fund is growing fast.

senses.sense: money needed or available to spend on something
senses.dict_examp: The charity closed down due to lack of funds.
senses.lear_examp: Due to the limited funds available to the committee responsible for the festivities, the location was not in accordance with the expectations.

senses.sense: to provide the money to pay for an event, activity or organization
senses.dict_examp: The company has agreed to fund my trip to Australia.
senses.lear_examp: This way would be a faster and more fair way to fund the changes that are to be made.

senses.sense: making you feel annoyed or discouraged
senses.dict_examp: a frustrating situation
senses.lear_examp: When you are working and you are in a hurry to get to your work place on time, waiting for the bus becomes quite annoying and frustrating.

senses.sense: Frozen food has been made so that it will last a long time by freezing.
senses.dict_examp: We don't have any fresh vegetables, only frozen peas.
senses.lear_examp: Nowadays, we do not need anymore to spend hours cooking, we just put some frozen food in the microwave, and in a few minutes our meal is ready.

senses.sense: turned into ice
senses.dict_examp: They skated over the frozen lake.

senses.sense: If a person, or a part of their body is frozen, they are very cold.
senses.dict_examp: Is there any heating in here? I'm frozen!
senses.lear_examp: I was frozen, but after a second I had a big silly smile on my face.

senses.sense: in a very angry way
senses.dict_examp: "Get out of here!" she shouted furiously.
senses.lear_examp: "Put that light out", I shouted furiously after those sleepless nights.

senses.sense: more or extra
senses.dict_examp: For further details about the offer, call this number.
senses.lear_examp: For further information, contact Joey Hung.

senses.sense: additional
senses.dict_examp: A further 20 stores will open next year.
senses.lear_examp: As a matter of fact, only 5% of the total income was taken to pay for administration costs, and a further 10% to pay for the cost of entertainment.

senses.sense: (comparative of far) at or to a place or time that is a longer distance away
senses.dict_examp: Let's walk a bit further down the road.
senses.lear_examp: When we left your place we drove on the motorway to Trier and further on to Luxembourg.

senses.sense: more
senses.dict_examp: He refused to discuss the matter further.
senses.lear_examp: I demand a full refund or I will be forced to take this matter further.

senses.sense: to make something develop or become more successful
senses.dict_examp: He'll do anything to further his career.
senses.lear_examp: This could be because some Education graduates were already in the  education field and pursuing a graduate course was a means of furthering their career or knowledge.

senses.sense: when people become excited, annoyed, or anxious about something, especially something unimportant
senses.dict_examp: What was all the fuss about?
senses.lear_examp: The Internet contains more information than any library, more easily accessible and without the fuss of library cards or the risk of losing books.

senses.sense: the thick hair that covers the bodies of some animals, like cats or rabbits
senses.dict_examp: She stroked the rabbit's soft fur.
senses.lear_examp: I find the killing of animals for fur an awful, disgusting thing.

senses.sense: extremely angry
senses.dict_examp: I was late and he was furious with me.
senses.lear_examp: He was absolutely furious, having learned about our engagement.

senses.sense: most distant
senses.dict_examp: That's the furthest I can see without glasses.

senses.sense: in a basic and important way
senses.dict_examp: Nothing has fundamentally changed.
senses.lear_examp: Japanese gardens are fundamentally different from those designed in Europe.

senses.sense: in addition to what has just been said
senses.dict_examp: Furthermore, we have a duty to defend our country.
senses.lear_examp: I am 22 years of age and I have a degree in tourism. Furthermore, I have a working knowledge of English, Spanish, Catalan and Italian.

senses.sense: a ceremony for burying or burning the body of a dead person
senses.dict_examp: The funeral will be held next Friday.
senses.lear_examp: She was crying at his funeral.

senses.sense: only liking particular things and very difficult to please
senses.dict_examp: She's a very fussy eater.
senses.lear_examp: When visiting a foreign country it may be difficult not to be fussy about food as well, and again, that is because of habits.

senses.sense: too careful about unimportant details
senses.dict_examp: He's very fussy about keeping his car clean.
senses.lear_examp: And this importance of presentation and almost fussy preciseness are reflected in our tradition.

senses.sense: If a room or building is furnished, there is furniture in it.
senses.dict_examp: He's renting a fully furnished apartment by the river.
senses.lear_examp: I am looking for a two bedroom, fully furnished apartment.

senses.sense: extreme anger or force
senses.dict_examp: The storm raged with mounting fury.
senses.lear_examp: It does not happen a lot that I sit down in anger and fury to write an open letter to the "Esslebury Gazette."

senses.sense: in grammar, the form of the verb used when talking about something that will happen or exist
senses.dict_examp: In the sentence "Who will look after the dog?" the verb phrase "will look" is in the future.

senses.sense: the time that is to come
senses.dict_examp: Do you worry about the future?
senses.lear_examp: We talked about old times and about the future.

senses.sense: beginning from now
senses.dict_examp: I promise I'll be more careful in the future.
senses.lear_examp: So hopefully she will follow my advice a little bit better in the future.

senses.sense: the chance of continuing to exist or succeed
senses.dict_examp: There's no future in this line of work.
senses.lear_examp: After his father's death, he didn't want to study, so he left university, losing a good future.

senses.sense: what will happen to someone or something in the time that is to come
senses.dict_examp: We need to discuss the future of the company.
senses.lear_examp: I think the 24/7 concept is the future of shops, and the main reason is that it can suit the type of life of any person.

senses.sense: at a time that is not far away
senses.dict_examp: Space travel may become very common in the near future.
senses.lear_examp: I look forward to receiving your reply in the near future.

senses.sense: as far in the future as you can imagine
senses.dict_examp: Prices will remain high for the foreseeable future.
senses.lear_examp: But in my view these same jobs will find themselves subjected to the same pressures and thus will have the same destiny in the foreseeable future.

senses.sense: happening or existing in the time which is to come
senses.dict_examp: future plans
senses.lear_examp: I think that it will be very important for my future career.

senses.sense: making you smile or laugh
senses.dict_examp: Do you know any funny stories/jokes?
senses.lear_examp: We danced, drank coca-cola, and watched a  very funny film.

senses.sense: strange, surprising, unexpected or difficult to explain or understand
senses.dict_examp: He's got some funny ideas about how to bring up children.
senses.lear_examp: We often see people talking about fitness and health, but the funny thing for me is that everybody really looks worried about it although they don't do anything to make it better.

senses.sense: money available for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: The company received state funding for the project.
senses.lear_examp: The Club doesn't need auxiliary funding, because it uses the money from membership fees.

senses.sense: objects such as chairs, tables, and beds that you put into a room or building
senses.dict_examp: They have a lot of antique furniture.
senses.lear_examp: I hurt myself one week ago so I can't help you but pupils can install chairs and the other furniture.
